div.p: I am sorry to have been so remiss about writing to you The fact is I have been forcing the pace rather in order to finish the " Outline " That is now done + sent to the publisher so I can get on with my arrears of correspondence.

About your book I am trying to get a grant from the University to enable it to be published but shall not know til April how much they will contribute. ( The Grants Committee does not meet till then. ) I have hopes however that they will be able
to do what is necessary.

I think your introduction is quite all right but I have ventured to add some short explanation about the principal vowels Also I think the vowel chart may want some slight alterations In it you have shown some distinctions so minute as to be practically inappreciable I mean for instance that if your i is appreciably lower + more retracted than Cardinal i the dot should be further away from the corner Thus is practically meaningless I hardly think you can get an appreciable distinction with a less distance than or
Similarly with the degree of advancement of some of your back vowels An u placed thus is not appreciably different from Cardinal u To get an appreciable distinction you must have a distance of say Some time I will go over them with Miss Lund + send you such emendations as seem to me desirable.
It is most kind of you to suggest dedicating the book to me Certainly you may do so if you like.

Your suggestion of it is ingenious but I think hardly feasible Ø is already not a very good letter and it is still less good ( from the legibility point of view ); the little hole at the bottom would always get
filled with ink in printing Also there is no satisfying handwriting form that I can see.

My impression is that the proper symbol for y is ( script , involving using regularly for ) This symbol already exists ( for Russian ), + the likeness between it and doesn ' t matter since French is not a separate phoneme.
I think the time is not yet ripe for mentioning this matter to the Council But it will have to be faced sooner or later.

About your book on General Phonetics which I am very glad to hear of you may certainly reproduce the I.P.A. versions of the " North Wind " Some of them want a little revising If you let me know in due course which ones you want I could send you the emendations.
Can you get American publishers to cut I.P.A. type properly If your book is for Americans you might consider the advisability of using African transcription ( y for j c for tʃ j for dʒ ɣ for y ).
I shall be seeing Westermann shortly ( in March ), + will enquire
about your prospects I have an idea that they are good but of course you must manage to get a degree somehow.

I hope you won ' t stay in America longer than you can possibly help I feel strongly that your proper place ( from the point of view of the promotion of phonetics ) is Europe Your work in America may be interesting + the life may be pleasant but you will be able to do work of wider and more permanent value on this side of the Atlantic.
I trust you are both very fit + enjoying life.
